title: Creates a temporary state commission on remanufacturing; appropriation
summary: Creates a temporary state commission on remanufacturing; provides for the appointment of members of the board of the commission; enumerates the goals and purposes of the commission; lists the powers of the board; requires the commission to submit a report to the governor and the legislature containing its findings and legislative recommendations; appropriates funds therefor.

       Introduced  by M. of A. MORELLE -- read once and referred to the Commit-
         tee on Economic Development

       AN ACT creating a temporary state commission on remanufacturing;  making
         an  appropriation  therefor;  and  providing  for  the  repeal of such
         provisions upon expiration thereof

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Legislative findings and intent. The legislature finds that
    2  New  York  state's remanufacturing industry, which is composed of a wide
    3  array of businesses, many of which are  small  businesses,  is  a  vital
    4  sector  of  the  economy,  employing thousands of people while diverting
    5  thousands of tons of waste from entering our  landfills.  Remanufactured
    6  products  are  the  highest form of recycling, and are supplied from our
    7  largest growth sector, small businesses. Based  on  these  findings  the
    8  legislature  finds  and  declares that the state should actively seek to
    9  enhance the remanufacturing industry and increase awareness of the bene-
   10  fits of remanufactured products.
   11    S 2. A temporary state commission, to be known as the temporary  state
   12  commission  on  remanufacturing,  hereinafter referred to as the commis-
   13  sion, is hereby  created  to  develop  programs  and  policies  for  the
   14  purposes  of  enhancing  and  fostering the introduction, expansion, and
   15  growth of the remanufacturing industry in New York state, and remanufac-
   16  turing efforts among state agencies.
   17    S 3. The commission shall consist of 12 members  to  be  appointed  as
   18  follows:  one  member  representing  the office of general services; one
   19  member representing the New York state solid waste management board; two
   20  members to be appointed by the governor; two members to be appointed  by
   21  the  temporary  president  of the senate; two members to be appointed by
   22  the speaker of the assembly; one member to be appointed by the  minority
   23  leader  of the senate; one member to be appointed by the minority leader
   24  of the assembly; one member shall be the president of the New York state

    1  energy research and development authority or his or  her  designee;  and
    2  one  to  be  appointed  by the comptroller. The appointees shall include
    3  representatives of the remanufacturing industry and  government  sectors
    4  and of the public at large. The speaker shall designate the chairman and
    5  vice-chairman.  Vacancies  in the membership of the commission and among
    6  its officers shall  be  filled  in  the  manner  provided  for  original
    7  appointments.
    8    S  4.  The  commission  in  conjunction with a not-for-profit research
    9  university located in New York state that is  nationally  recognized  as
   10  having expertise in remanufacturing issues, shall:
   11    (a)  target  industries which would have a positive effect on New York
   12  state and its residents and would be beneficial to  the  financial  well
   13  being of this state;
   14    (b)  develop programs with New York state colleges and universities to
   15  train students to work in the selected target industries;
   16    (c) assess the use of remanufactured products in New York state  agen-
   17  cies, boards, authorities, commissions, courts, and colleges;
   18    (d) assist agencies in promoting broader awareness of the availability
   19  and  performance  attributes  of  remanufactured  products in the market
   20  place.   Educational efforts should be  directed  to  consumers  through
   21  agency  publications,  conferences,  and  encouragement  of manufacturer
   22  disclosures where the manufacturer's cooperation can be  secured.  Those
   23  involved  should  include: the department of environmental conservation,
   24  department of economic development, office of general services, consumer
   25  protection board, environmental facilities  corporation,  department  of
   26  transportation, and the legislature;
   27    (e)  in  order to encourage the increased use of remanufactured goods,
   28  the commission shall recommend the development of appropriate industrial
   29  standards to assure quality performance;
   30    (f) conduct a survey of remanufacturing activities in New  York  state
   31  in  cooperation  with  industry  and academic institutions, to develop a
   32  database from which policies to advance the marketing of  remanufactured
   33  goods can be identified; and
   34    (g)  institute a public outreach campaign to inform the general public
   35  and state agency purchasing officials on the benefits of  using  remanu-
   36  factured  products  and  to  address  concerns  regarding  availability,
   37  performance, and quality of such products.  Such campaign shall include,
   38  but not be limited to developing printed informational materials promot-
   39  ing the benefits of using remanufactured products.   Such  informational
   40  material  shall  be  available  in  both  English  and  Spanish language
   41  versions and may include but not be limited to the following:
   42    (1) The remanufacturing industry is a vital sector of New York state's
   43  economy, employing thousands of people, including  providing  employment
   44  opportunities  for  people  with  disabilities  and  those seeking to be
   45  removed from the welfare rolls;
   46    (2) Remanufacturing restores durable products to serve their  original
   47  function by replacing worn or damaged parts;
   48    (3)  The  use of remanufactured products prevents thousands of tons of
   49  solid waste from entering our landfills, conserves  energy  and  natural
   50  resources, and is the highest form of recycling; and
   51    (4)  Purchasing remanufactured products can save as much as 50 percent
   52  of the cost of purchasing new products.
   53    S 5. The commission may employ and at pleasure remove  such  personnel
   54  as  it  may  deem necessary for the performance of its functions and fix
   55  their compensation within the amounts made available therefor.

       A. 4059                             3

    1    S 6. The commission may meet within and without the state, shall  hold
    2  public  hearings, and shall have all the powers of a legislative commit-
    3  tee pursuant to the legislative law.
    4    S  7.  The members of the commission shall receive no compensation for
    5  their services, but shall be allowed their actual and necessary expenses
    6  incurred in the performance of their duties hereunder.
    7    S 8. To the maximum extent feasible, the commission shall be  entitled
    8  to  request  and  receive  and  shall  utilize and be provided with such
    9  facilities, resources, and data  of  any  court,  department,  division,
   10  board,  bureau,  commission,  or  agency  of  the state or any political
   11  subdivision thereof as it deems necessary  or  desirable  to  carry  out
   12  properly its powers and duties hereunder.
   13    S  9.  The  commission shall make a preliminary report to the governor
   14  and the legislature of its findings,  conclusions,  and  recommendations
   15  not later than March 1, 2013 and a final report of its findings, conclu-
   16  sions,  and  recommendations  not  later  than  March 1, 2014, and shall
   17  submit with its reports such legislative proposals as it deems necessary
   18  to implement its recommendations.
   19    S 10. The sum of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000), or  so
   20  much  thereof  as may be necessary, is hereby appropriated to the tempo-
   21  rary state commission created pursuant to section two of this  act  from
   22  any  moneys  in  the state treasury in the general fund to the credit of
   23  the local assistance account not otherwise appropriated for services and
   24  expenses of  the  commission  for  the  purposes  of  carrying  out  the
   25  provisions  of  this  act.  Such  sum  shall be payable on the audit and
   26  warrant of the state comptroller on vouchers certified  or  approved  by
   27  the  chair  of such commission, or the chair's duly designated represen-
   28  tative in the manner provided by law. No expenditure shall be made  from
   29  this appropriation until a certificate of approval of availability shall
   30  have  been issued by the director of the budget and filed with the state
   31  comptroller and a copy filed  with  the  chair  of  the  senate  finance
   32  committee  and  the chair of the assembly ways and means committee. Such
   33  certificate may be amended from time to time  by  the  director  of  the
   34  budget  and  a copy of each such amendment shall be filed with the state
   35  comptroller, the chair of the senate finance committee and the chair  of
   36  the assembly ways and means committee.
   37    S  11.  Within the amounts appropriated therefor, the commission shall
   38  make grants for the following purposes:
   39    (a) to increase the numbers and improve the training of  remanufactur-
   40  ers;
   41    (b)  to improve procedures for the testing of remanufactured products;
   42  and
   43    (c) create a tax credit or other similar incentives.
   44    S 12. This act shall take effect on  the  one  hundred  eightieth  day
   45  after  it  shall  have  become a law; and shall remain in full force and
   46  effect until March 31, 2014, when upon such date the provisions of  this
   47  act shall expire and be deemed repealed.
